context.p: The enable/disable circuit is accessed from the CCB’s J17 plug inside the CCB enclosure. See to locate the CCB enclosure. Install field wiring to the enable/disable circuit:

step.cmd: Turn off power at the water heater’s Enable/Disable switch and the breaker that supplies power to the water heater.
Carefully remove the temperature-probe connectors and the CCB enclosure cover.
Locate pins 1 and 2 on the CCB J17 plug. See .
Connect the two field-supplied control wires to pins 1 and 2 on the CCB J17 plug.

Thread the control wires out of the CCB enclosure with the other wiring and carefully replace the CCB enclosure cover. Ensure all wiring is routed through the intended area provided for strain relief. Ensure that no wiring is being pinched.
Reinstall the CCB enclosure cover and temperature-probe connectors.
Route the control wires inside the junction box on the top of the water heater. See to locate the junction box. Use an available knock-out to route the wires inside the junction box.

Install field-supplied control wiring and conduit, as required by national and local codes, between the water heater’s junction box and the external supervisory control. Connect the wiring from the external control to the control wires inside the junction box using wire nuts and electrical tape.
Connect the control wiring to a set of dry contacts on the external control. Follow the control manufacturer’s instructions for making connections.
Restore power to the water heater.
From the water heaters user interface module (UIM) Heater Information screen, select Use External Enable and change the value to Yes. See to locate the UIM.

info.note: Whenever the external control opens the set of dry contacts used, water heating operation is disabled. Whenever the external control closes the set of dry contacts used, water heating operation is enabled. A diagonal line and circle appears over the thermometer icon on the UIM when water heating operation is disabled. See .

Ensure that the water heater is protected from freezing temperatures when water heating operation is disabled. Damage to the water heater that is caused by freezing temperatures is not covered under the limited warranty. See Commercial Water Heater Limited Warranty.
